questions.text:
You are a primary care physician seeing a patient for a routine check-up. The patient expresses concern about colon cancer and asks about potential risk factors and preventive measures. You provide the following information: (INICET NOV 2021)

 

  1. Right and left colon cancers can exhibit distinct behaviour.
  2. Colon cancer can have hereditary components.
  3. Colon cancer risk can be mitigated by metformin.
  4. Liver metastases are a common occurrence in colon cancer.

 

Which of the following options is/are true regarding colon cancer:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1, 2, 3, and 4

 

All the 4 statements given are true about colon cancer.

 

  • Right and left colon cancers exhibit different characteristics, with left-sided tumors being more likely to cause obstruction due to the caliber of the bowel and consistency of stool.
  • Proximal colon cancers, or right colon cancers, are typically diagnosed later and may present with iron deficiency anemia or a mass.
  • While the majority of colorectal cancers occur sporadically, some can be hereditary and are more common in patients with a family history of the disease, like FAP and HNPCC. Genetic testing can aid in early diagnosis.
  • Metformin, a biguanide compound used to treat diabetes, has been shown to reduce the risk of colorectal cancer by disrupting cellular energy supply and inhibiting aerobic glycolysis.
  • Liver metastasis is the most frequent site of distant metastasis in colorectal cancer and occurs through hematogenous spread via the portal venous system. Tumor size and grade are risk factors. The second most common site of distant metastasis is the lung, while carcinomatosis can occur through peritoneal seeding.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements regarding Vacuum-Assisted Closure (VAC) dressing are correct? (INICET MAY 2025)

 

  1. Reduces bacterial load 
  2. Maximum pressure is -125mm of Hg 
  3. Promotes granulation tissue 
  4. Reduces size of wound
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1, 2, 3 and 4

 

VAC (Vacuum Assisted Closure) dressing, also known as Negative Pressure Wound Therapy (NPWT), is a therapeutic technique that uses controlled negative pressure to promote wound healing. All four statements about VAC dressing are correct.

 

1. Reduces bacterial load 

 

  • VAC therapy uses controlled negative pressure to draw out excess fluid and infectious materials from the wound bed.
  • It decreases local bacterial colonization, helps prevent infection, and supports a cleaner wound environment.
  • This effect enhances the wound's ability to heal efficiently.

 

2.  Maximum pressure is -125 mmHg 

 

  • The standard therapeutic range for VAC dressing is between -75 mmHg to -125 mmHg.
  • -125 mmHg is considered the maximum standard pressure used for optimal clinical benefit.
  • Lower pressures may be used in certain cases, but -125 mmHg is the commonly applied maximum.

 

3.  Promotes granulation tissue 

 

  • The negative pressure improves blood perfusion and oxygen delivery to the wound, encouraging angiogenesis.
  • It promotes the formation of healthy granulation tissue, which is essential for wound healing and epithelialization.

 

4. Reduces size of wound 

 

  • The vacuum effect draws the edges of the wound inward through mechanical approximation, thereby reducing wound dimensions.
  • Over time, this leads to a noticeable decrease in wound size, making it easier to manage and close.

 

Educational Objective:

 

VAC therapy at -100 to -125 mmHg reduces bacterial load through continuous drainage, promotes granulation tissue by improving vascularity and removing MMPs, and mechanically approximates wound edges to reduce wound size.

questions.text: Which of the following types of renal stones are produced by laxative abuse? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Ammonium urate

 

Ammonium urate stones are most likely to be seen in patients with laxative abuse.

 

Ammonium urate stones are composed of a combination of ammonia and uric acid. When laxatives are abused, they cause metabolic alkalosis. This alkaline environment can lead to the formation of ammonium urate stones, as ammonium is more soluble in alkaline urine than in acidic urine.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Uric acid: Uric acid stones form when the urine is persistently acidic, which can occur in conditions like gout or diseases that cause rapid cell turnover like tumor lysis syndrome. A diet high in purines, certain types of medications, and some genetic factors can contribute to uric acid stone formation. However, these stones are not typically associated with laxative abuse.

 

Option C. Struvite: Struvite stones, also known as infection stones, are associated with urinary tract infections caused by certain bacteria. These bacteria can produce urease, which splits urea in to ammonia, that makes the urine more alkaline, which can lead to struvite stone formation. They are not directly associated with laxative abuse.

 

Option D. Calcium oxalate: Calcium oxalate stones are the most common type of kidney stone. Factors that increase the urine concentration of these constituents can contribute to stone formation. The absorption of oxalate might increase with chronic diarrhea (a potential consequence of laxative abuse), which can contribute to the formation of calcium oxalate stones, however this is not a common feature.

 

Educational Objective:


Laxative abuse can lead to metabolic alkalosis, which creates an alkaline urinary environment, predisposing to the formation of ammonium urate stones.

choices.text: Spread of tumor to anterior chest wall

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman discovered a lump in her breast during a self-examination. She immediately scheduled an appointment with her primary care physician for further evaluation. On examination by the doctor this was noticed.  What is the cause for the following skin change? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Infiltration of subdermal lymphatics

 

  • When the subdermal lymphatic vessels, which are responsible for draining lymph fluid from the tissues, are infiltrated or blocked by cancer cells, it can cause edema or swelling in the skin.
  • This can lead to skin changes resembling the dimpled surface of an orange, known as "peau d'orange."
  • The infiltration of subdermal lymphatics with tumor cells leads to the appearance of skin thickening and pores becoming more prominent, which is characteristic of peau d'orange.

 

Other Options :

 

Option B. Infiltration of lactiferous duct: Infiltration or blockage of these ducts might lead to nipple retraction.

 

Option C. Involvement of Cooper's ligament: Cooper's ligaments are fibrous tissues that provide structural support to the breast. They help in maintaining the shape and position of the breast. Cancer can invade these ligaments and cause dimpling.

 

Option D. Spread of tumor to anterior chest wall: If a breast tumor spreads to the anterior chest wall, it can cause fixation of the breast to the chest, making the breast immobile.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Peau d'orange is a skin change indicative of underlying breast cancer where subdermal lymphatic infiltration leads to edema and skin dimpling resembling the surface of an orange.

choices.text: Triangle of death and circle of death
Triangle of doom and circle of death
Triangle of doom medially and triangle of pain laterally
Triangle of doom laterally and triangle of pain medially

questions.text: The Trapezoid of Disaster includes: (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Triangle of doom medially and triangle of pain laterally

 

Explanation:

 

During laparoscopic hernia repair, the surgeon must navigate important anatomical landmarks in the inguinal region. The "Trapezoid of Disaster" contains two important triangles that require careful attention during mesh placement. The Triangle of Doom is bounded medially by the vas deferens and laterally by the testicular vessels, containing the external iliac vessels and genital branch of genitofemoral nerve. The Triangle of Pain is located lateral to this, bounded medially by testicular vessels and laterally by the iliopubic tract, containing the femoral nerve, anterior cutaneous nerve of thigh, and lateral cutaneous nerve of thigh.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A: "Triangle of death" is anatomically known as the triangle of “doom”.
  • Option B: "Triangle of doom and circle of death" do not form a trapezoid of disaster.
  • Option D: This reverses the correct orientation. The Triangle of Doom is medial and the Triangle of Pain is lateral, not the opposite.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The Triangle of Doom contains vital vascular structures (external iliac vessels) while the Triangle of Pain contains important nerves (femoral nerve, cutaneous nerves). Accurate identification of these anatomical landmarks is crucial to prevent iatrogenic injury during laparoscopic hernia repair.

questions.text: A patient came to the OPD with a history of burn wound on the lower limb. His wound is given in the picture. What is the probable diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Marjolin's Ulcer

 

The patient has a history of a burn wound on the lower limb. The image shows a chronic wound with changes typical of Marjolin's ulcer. Marjolin's ulcer is a type of squamous cell carcinoma that occurs in chronic wounds. This transformation is due to chronic irritation to the skin, which increases the risk of developing squamous cell carcinoma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Venous Ulcer: This is incorrect because venous ulcers typically occur in patients with chronic venous insufficiency and are usually located on the medial aspect of the ankle.

 

Option C. Arterial Ulcer: This is incorrect because arterial ulcers are associated with peripheral arterial disease and are usually found on the toes, feet, or lateral aspect of the ankle.

 

Option D. Infected burn wound: This is incorrect because an infected burn wound would not necessarily show the chronic changes typical of Marjolin's ulcer, which includes malignant transformation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Marjolin's ulcer is a type of squamous cell carcinoma that occurs in chronic wounds, including long-standing burn wounds.

questions.text: A 29-year-old pregnant woman in 7th week of pregnancy presents with right lower abdominal quadrant pain. She was diagnosed with acute appendicitis. What is the best management for this patient? (FMGE DEC 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Immediate Laparoscopic appendectomy

 

Immediate laparoscopic appendectomy is the most appropriate treatment for acute appendicitis in a pregnant patient to prevent potential complications for both the mother and the fetus. Laparoscopic appendectomy is a minimally invasive surgical procedure to remove the appendix, typically performed in the first two trimesters. This method is preferred due to advantages such as reduced postoperative pain, quicker recovery, and fewer postoperative complications compared to open surgery. Delaying surgery in cases of acute appendicitis increases the risk of complications like rupture, abscess formation, fetal loss, or preterm birth.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Wait till 28 weeks of pregnancy: Waiting to perform surgery until 28 weeks of pregnancy is inappropriate for acute appendicitis. Delaying treatment can lead to serious complications such as rupture or abscess formation, which can increase the risk of fetal loss or preterm birth. While surgical intervention in the second trimester is considered safer, it is not advisable to wait in acute conditions.

 

Option C. Oschner Sherren regimen: This regimen is used for conservative management of an appendicular mass, which develops when there is delayed presentation of appendicitis and the body walls off the inflammation, forming a palpable lump. It involves bed rest, antibiotics, and nil by mouth until symptoms subside. This regimen is not appropriate for acute appendicitis without lump formation.

 

Option D. MTP (Medical Termination of Pregnancy): Termination of pregnancy would not be the first line of management for appendicitis. It would only be considered if there were significant complications that endangered the mother's life or if the fetus showed signs of distress or anomalies. In this scenario, the primary recommendation is to address the acute appendicitis surgically.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The appropriate management of acute appendicitis in a pregnant patient is immediate laparoscopic appendectomy to prevent complications for both the mother and the fetus.

questions.text: In a triage setting, which of the following categories requires the highest priority intervention? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Red

 

In a triage setting, particularly in emergency and disaster scenarios, different colors are used to categorize the urgency of patients' conditions. 

 

This indicates that the patient has life-threatening injuries and requires immediate intervention to save their life. Patients in this category are to be treated first.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Yellow: This signifies that the patient has serious injuries that are not immediately life-threatening. Their treatment can be delayed briefly, but they still need urgent care.

 

Option C. Green: This color is used for patients with minor injuries who are stable enough to wait for a longer period without immediate intervention. These are the "walking wounded."

 

Option D. Black: This category is used for patients who are either deceased or have such extensive injuries that they are not expected to survive given the level of care available. In a mass casualty incident, these patients may be deemed beyond help and may not receive treatment due to limited resources.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

In triage, patients categorized as 'Red' require the highest priority intervention due to the life-threatening nature of their injuries and the necessity of immediate treatment to save their lives.

questions.text: A patient presents to the OPD with an ulcerative lesion noted near the nose/medical canthus. What is the probable diagnosis? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Basal cell carcinoma 

 

  • The patient's presentation with an ulcerative lesion near the nose/medial canthus with rolled out edges is a basal cell carcinoma. 

 

This is the most common type of skin cancer, often appearing in sun-exposed areas such as the face. BCC frequently presents as a pearly bump with telangiectatic vessels or as a flat, flesh-colored or brown scar-like lesion. Ulceration is common in neglected or advanced BCC, particularly near critical areas like the nose and eyes, where it can cause significant local destruction. Given its common presentation and the description provided, BCC is a very likely diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lentigo Maligna Melanoma: This is a type of melanoma that typically occurs on sun-exposed areas of the skin, particularly the face and the arms, in older adults. It begins as a patch that darkens, enlarges, and sometimes becomes nodular, indicating progression to melanoma. It's less common for lentigo maligna to present initially as an ulcerative lesion, making this a less likely diagnosis.

 

Option C. Squamous Cell Carcinoma (SCC): SCC is a type of skin cancer that can also appear on sun-exposed skin and may develop from a pre-existing actinic keratosis. It can be more aggressive than BCC and typically presents as a thick, rough, scaly patch that can bleed if bumped. It can ulcerate but often has a more rapid growth compared to BCC.

 

Option D. Nevus: A nevus is a common skin growth (mole), which can be present from birth or appear during childhood or young adulthood. While most nevi are benign, changes in their appearance, such as ulceration, require evaluation to rule out malignant transformation, such as into melanoma.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Given the description of an ulcerative lesion near critical areas like the nose and medial canthus, Basal Cell Carcinoma is the most probable diagnosis due to its frequent occurrence in these regions and its tendency to ulcerate. Treatment typically involves surgical excision, and in some cases, topical or systemic therapy may be considered.

questions.text: What instrument is used to insert this tube?
questions.solution:
Ans.  B) Cysto-Urethroscope

 

The image depicts a double J (DJ) stent placed in the ureter, commonly used to keep the ureter patent, especially after procedures like Percutaneous Nephrolithotomy (PCNL) or Extracorporeal Shock Wave Lithotripsy (ESWL). The correct method for inserting or removing this stent is through cystoscopy or cysto-urethroscopy, which involves visualizing the ureteric orifices and directly inserting the stent into the desired ureter.

 

Cysto-urethroscopy allows the surgeon to view the bladder and the openings of the ureters, facilitating the accurate placement of the stent without needing to enter the ureter directly. This approach is similar to the technique used in Endoscopic Retrograde Cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) for biliary stenting, where a stent is placed via the ampulla using an endoscope, rather than inserting a scope into the duct itself.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nephroscope: A nephroscope is used for direct visualization of the kidney's interior, typically for removing stones or other intrarenal procedures, not for inserting ureteral stents.

 

Option C. Ureteroscope: While ureteroscopes are used for procedures directly within the ureter, such as stone removal, the insertion of DJ stents is typically done via cystoscopy, not ureteroscopy.

 

Option D. USG guided: Ultrasound guidance is not commonly used for placing ureteral stents as it does not provide the visual access needed to navigate the ureteric orifices.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The insertion of a double J stent in the ureter is performed using a cysto-urethroscope, which allows for direct visualization of the bladder and ureteric orifices, enabling accurate stent placement.

questions.text: Hepatic avulsions are classified as what grade according to the AAST liver injury scale? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Grade V 

 

Explanation:

 

Hepatic avulsions are classified as Grade V in the AAST liver injury scale. This represents the highest grade of liver injury, reflecting complete detachment of the liver or severe damage to major vascular pedicles. The AAST grading system categorizes liver injuries progressively from minor lacerations to complete avulsion, with Grade V being the most severe form.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Grade I - Incorrect Grade I liver injuries only involve minor lacerations less than 1cm in depth. These are superficial injuries that don't involve vascular structures and typically heal without surgical intervention.

 

Option B. Grade II - Incorrect Grade II liver injuries involve lacerations between 1-3cm in depth but don't involve major vascular structures. These moderate injuries are far less severe than complete avulsions.

 

Option C. Grade IV - Incorrect Grade IV liver injuries involve parenchymal disruption affecting 25-75% of one hepatic lobe. While serious, these don't constitute complete avulsion of the liver.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hepatic avulsion represents the most severe form of liver trauma in the AAST classification system and is designated as Grade V. Management of such injuries typically requires damage control surgery with the "4 Ps" approach: Push, Pack, Plug, and Pringle maneuver.

choices.text: Genetic counselling and screening for BRA

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman with a family history of breast and ovarian cancer is seeking advice about her risk for developing breast cancer. She is currently taking oral contraceptive pills and is concerned about her risk. Which of the following is the next best step in management? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Genetic counselling and screening for BRA

 

  • A family history of breast and ovarian cancer in close relatives with one of the relatives having an onset before the age of 50 years indicates a high risk for breast cancer.
  • The next step in management is genetic counselling and screening for BRA.
  • This involves discussing various genetic testing options such as BRCA testing and multiple gene panel testing.
  • Genetic testing is recommended for high-risk women with a family history of breast or ovarian cancer, particularly if the diagnosis was made before age 50, if there are multiple affected family members, or if the patient has a personal history of breast or ovarian cancer.
  • Mammography is not the initial investigation of choice but can be used for surveillance after genetic screening.
  • Discontinuing oral contraceptive pills is not necessary as they do not increase the risk of breast cancer in women with a positive family history of breast cancer.

 

Given the patient's family history of breast and ovarian cancer, as well as her concerns about her risk, the next best step is to offer genetic counseling and testing for BRCA1 and BRCA2 mutations. These genetic mutations are associated with an increased risk of breast and ovarian cancer. Understanding her genetic risk can help the patient make informed decisions about her healthcare, including potential surveillance and risk-reduction strategies.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Routine mammography: Routine mammography is a screening tool for breast cancer, but it is typically recommended for women starting at around age 40 or 50, depending on guidelines and individual risk factors. While it's an important part of breast cancer screening, it may not be the most appropriate initial step in this case, given the patient's family history and concerns.

 

Option C. Stop taking oral contraceptive pills: While hormonal factors can be associated with a slight increase in breast cancer risk, discontinuing oral contraceptive pills may not be the primary step in managing a patient with a strong family history of breast and ovarian cancer. Genetic counseling and testing for BRCA mutations would provide more specific information about her risk.

 

Option D. Prophylactic surgery: Prophylactic surgery, such as a bilateral mastectomy or oophorectomy, may be considered in individuals with known BRCA mutations who have a high risk of breast and ovarian cancer. However, this step would be taken after genetic counseling and testing to determine the patient's risk and suitability for such procedures. It is not the initial step in management.

choices.text: Arterial disease involving the superficial femoral artery
Arterial disease involving the profunda femoris artery

questions.text: A 60-year-old man, a habitual smoker, visits the hospital. He describes experiencing recurring pain in his thighs and buttocks when he walks, particularly noticeable after covering a distance of approximately 500 meters. What could be a plausible diagnosis for his symptoms?(NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Arterial disease with aortoiliac involvement

 

Explanation:

 

  • The given clinical scenario is suggestive of arterial disease with intermittent claudication due to aortoiliac occlusion. Claudication pain in the buttocks and thighs, particularly during walking, is a typical symptom of aortoiliac occlusive disease, also known as Leriche syndrome in more severe cases if associated with impotence.
  • The aortoiliac arteries are major blood vessels that supply the lower half of the body. Blockages in these arteries can lead to pain in the buttocks, thighs, or hips upon exertion. The claudication pain in the buttocks or thighs, as described by the patient, is a typical symptom of aortoiliac occlusive disease. Therefore, this is the most plausible diagnosis given the patient's symptoms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Arterial disease involving the superficial femoral artery: This type of arterial disease would involve blockage in the superficial femoral artery, which runs through the thigh. Patients with this condition typically experience claudication pain in the calf muscles because the superficial femoral artery primarily supplies the calf muscles.

 

Option C. Femoral venous insufficiency: Femoral venous insufficiency involves issues with the veins, not the arteries. This condition typically leads to symptoms like leg swelling, varicose veins, and skin changes, but it does not cause claudication or pain upon walking specific distances.

 

Option D. Arterial disease involving the profunda femoris artery: The profunda femoris artery is a deep artery of the thigh. Blockage in this artery can cause pain, but the pain would typically present differently from the described scenario. The location and type of pain would be more localized to the thigh rather than involving the buttocks.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Claudication pain in the buttocks and thighs during walking, particularly in a habitual smoker, is highly suggestive of arterial disease with aortoiliac involvement. This is characterized by blockages in the aortoiliac arteries, leading to decreased blood flow to the lower extremities.

questions.text: Open pre-peritoneal large mesh repair for complex inguinal hernia is associated with which of the following procedures? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Stoppa operation

 

Explanation:

            

The Stoppa operation is the open pre-peritoneal large mesh repair technique for complex inguinal hernias. This procedure involves placing a large prosthetic mesh in the pre-peritoneal space that covers the entire myopectineal orifice bilaterally. It's specifically designed for complex, recurrent, or bilateral inguinal hernias. The Stoppa approach provides excellent coverage of all potential hernia sites while avoiding direct contact with nerves in the inguinal canal, reducing the risk of chronic pain.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lichtenstein operation - Incorrect because the Lichtenstein repair is an onlay mesh technique where the prosthetic mesh is placed on top of the posterior wall of the inguinal canal, not in the pre-peritoneal space. While it uses mesh, it employs a different anatomical approach and placement technique.

 

Option B. Shouldice operation - Incorrect because the Shouldice repair is a tissue-based herniorrhaphy technique that doesn't use mesh at all. It involves multiple layers of suturing of the native tissue (double breasting of conjoint tendon and inguinal ligament and halves of fascia transversalis) to create a 4-layer posterior wall repair.

 

Option D. Mac-Vay Operation - Incorrect because the McVay (Cooper ligament) repair is another tissue-based repair that doesn't utilize mesh. This technique involves suturing the conjoint tendon to Cooper's ligament (pectineal ligament) rather than to the inguinal ligament.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The Stoppa operation is characterized by placement of a large prosthetic mesh in the pre-peritoneal space for complex inguinal hernias, covering bilateral myopectineal orifices simultaneously.

questions.text:
Match the following positions of the appendix: (INICET MAY 2023)

 

 

  1. Subcaecal
  2. Retrocaecal
  3. Inside the pelvis
  4. Paracaecal
questions.solution: Ans. C) 1-b, 2-d, 3-a, 4-c

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presents with progressive dysphagia, which is more pronounced for liquids than solids. A barium swallow study is performed. Which characteristic radiological finding is most likely to be observed? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Rat tail deformity

 

Explanation:

 

The clinical presentation strongly suggests achalasia cardia:

 

  • Young patient (25 years)
  • Dysphagia to both liquids and solids, with liquids being affected more
  • In achalasia, barium swallow characteristically shows a "bird beak" or "rat tail" appearance due to smooth tapering at the gastroesophageal junction with proximal dilation of esophagus
  • This appearance is due to failure of LES relaxation with preserved peristalsis in body of esophagus, which is the hallmark of achalasia

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Smooth filling defect: Incorrect as this suggests a benign mass/tumor 

 

Option C. Irregular filling defect: Incorrect as this suggests malignant mass causing infiltration of the esophageal wall

 

Option D. Corkscrew esophagus: Incorrect as this is seen in diffuse esophageal spasm where the primary symptom is chest pain rather than dysphagia

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rat tail/bird beak appearance on barium swallow is characteristic of achalasia cardia, which presents with dysphagia to liquids more than solids.

questions.text: Which of the following is correct regarding the X-Ray image shown? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Jejunal atresia

 

The X-ray image provided shows a characteristic feature known as the "triple bubble" appearance, which is indicative of jejunal atresia. In the context of pediatric radiology, this appearance is caused by the presence of three dilated gas-filled bowel loops proximal to the atretic segment of the jejunum. Jejunal atresia is a congenital condition where there is an obstruction in the jejunum, leading to this distinctive radiological sign.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Duodenal atresia: This condition typically presents with a "double bubble" sign on an X-ray, not a triple bubble. The double bubble sign shows two dilated areas—one in the stomach and one in the duodenum—due to an obstruction in the duodenum.

 

Option C. Pneumoperitoneum: This condition involves the presence of free air in the peritoneal cavity, usually due to gastrointestinal perforation. The X-ray sign is free air under the diaphragm, which is not seen in the given image.

 

Option D. Hirschsprung’s disease: This is a congenital condition characterized by the absence of ganglion cells in the distal colon, leading to obstruction. The radiographic features might include a distended colon with a transition zone, but it does not present with the triple bubble appearance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Radiological findings:

 

  • Jejunal atresia or ileal atresia: Triple Bubble Appearance
  • Duodenal atresia: Double Bubble sign
  • Infantile pyloric stenosis: Single Bubble sign

questions.text: What is the next best step in the management of a 16-year-old male with a painless large round firm right testicular swelling, with a dragging sensation and AFP around 5000? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) High inguinal orchidectomy

 

Testicular mass with elevated AFP is suggestive of testicular tumor, where the next best step in management for this patient is High inguinal orchidectomy

 

This is the correct choice for the initial management of a suspected malignant testicular tumor. The inguinal approach ensures that the scrotal skin and potential lymphatic drainage are not violated. This procedure allows for both definitive diagnosis (through histopathological examination) and therapeutic management by removing the tumor. An elevated AFP further supports the possibility of a germ cell tumor, such as a yolk sac tumor or non-seminomatous germ cell tumor, both of which warrant surgical removal

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. FNAC (Fine Needle Aspiration Cytology): While FNAC is a diagnostic procedure, it's not typically used in the primary evaluation of testicular masses due to the risk of tumor seeding along the needle track and is contraindicated.

 

Option B. Scrotal trucut biopsy: This is not recommended for suspected testicular tumors. Biopsying a testicular tumor through a scrotal approach can risk tumor spillage or seeding within the scrotum and can alter the lymphatic drainage pattern, thus complicating future treatment..

 

Option D. Repeat Tumor markers: While monitoring tumor markers like AFP is useful in the management and follow-up of testicular cancer, simply repeating the test without addressing the testicular mass would not be appropriate. The clinical findings and elevated AFP already provide strong evidence of malignancy, and action should be taken.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A painless testicular swelling in a young male with elevated AFP is highly suggestive of a testicular malignancy. The standard of care in such cases is to proceed with a high inguinal orchidectomy for both diagnostic and therapeutic purposes.

questions.text: Which of these is not a component/adjunct of the primary survey in trauma? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) CECT

 

Primary survey adjuncts include:

 

  • Chest X-ray
  • Pelvic X-ray
  • eFAST (Extended Focused Assessment with Sonography in Trauma)
  • ECG
  • Pulse oximetry
  • Arterial blood gas
  • Urinary catheter
  • Nasogastric tube
  • CECT is part of secondary survey, performed only in hemodynamically stable patients.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chest X-ray:

 

  • Essential adjunct to primary survey
  • Quickly identifies life-threatening conditions like pneumothorax, hemothorax

 

Option B. Pelvic X-ray:

 

  • Important adjunct in primary survey
  • Identifies pelvic fractures which can cause major hemorrhage
  • Guides immediate management decisions

 

Option C. Extended FAST :

 

  • Critical bedside tool in primary survey
  • Rapidly identifies free fluid in abdomen/chest
  • Particularly valuable in unstable patients

 

Educational Objective: 

 

CECT is not a component of primary survey - it belongs to secondary survey and is performed only in hemodynamically stable patients.

choices.text: Junction of upper and middle third of the sternomastoid muscle
Junction of middle and lower third of the sternomastoid muscle
Between the two heads of the sternomastoid muscle

questions.text: Which of these is the most common site of a branchial cyst? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Junction of upper and middle third of the sternomastoid muscle

Explanation:

 

The typical location for a branchial cyst is at the anterior border of the junction between the upper and middle third of the sternomastoid muscle. Branchial cysts are developmental anomalies that arise from the remnants of the second branchial cleft. They are lined by squamous epithelium and contain thick, cloudy fluid that often includes cholesterol crystals. This location is key for identifying and diagnosing branchial cysts.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Junction of middle and lower third of the sternomastoid muscle: This location is typically associated with the external opening of a branchial fistula, not a branchial cyst.

 

Option C. Middle of the sternomastoid muscle: This is not the usual site for branchial cysts. Branchial cysts are more commonly found at the anterior border of the upper and middle third junction.

 

Option D. Between the two heads of the sternomastoid muscle: This area is not associated with the typical location of branchial cysts. The cysts are more commonly found anterior to the sternomastoid muscle.

 

Additional Information on Branchial Cysts:

  • Origin: Congenital or acquired remnants of the second branchial cleft.
  • Lining: Squamous epithelium.
  • Contents: Thick, cloudy fluid with cholesterol crystals, sometimes clear fluid making the cyst soft and shiny.
  • Branchial Fistula: The external opening of a branchial fistula is at the junction of the middle and lower third of the anterior border of the sternocleidomastoid.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most common site for a branchial cyst is at the anterior border of the junction between the upper and middle third of the sternomastoid muscle.

questions.text: After parotid surgery, the patient is found to have weakness of the lower lip on the ipsilateral side. Which of these injuries is likely to produce this? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cervical branch of facial nerve

 

In this scenario, the patient has undergone parotid surgery and subsequently developed weakness of the lower lip on the same side as the surgery (ipsilateral). This kind of symptom indicates a nerve injury.

 

  • Facial Nerve Branches: The facial nerve (cranial nerve VII) is responsible for motor control of the muscles of facial expression. It divides into several branches after it exits the stylomastoid foramen, including the temporal, zygomatic, buccal, mandibular (marginal mandibular), and cervical branches.
  • Cervical Branch: The cervical branch of the facial nerve, along with the marginal mandibular branch, supplies the muscles of the lower face, including those involved in the movement of the lower lip. An injury to the cervical branch could result in weakness of the lower lip, which is consistent with the patient's presentation.
  • Marginal Mandibular Branch: Although the marginal mandibular branch is primarily responsible for the lower lip, in cases where this specific branch is not listed as an option, the cervical branch is the closest and most accurate choice because it is part of the lower division of the facial nerve that supplies the lower lip muscles.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Main trunk of the facial nerve: Injury to the main trunk of the facial nerve would likely cause more extensive symptoms, including the inability to close the eye (Bell's phenomenon), loss of forehead wrinkling, and other signs of lower motor neuron facial paralysis, which are not mentioned in this case. Therefore, this option is less likely.

 

Option B. Temporal branch of the facial nerve: The temporal branch of the facial nerve innervates muscles in the upper face, such as those involved in raising the eyebrows and closing the eyelids. It does not affect the lower lip, making this option incorrect.

 

Option D. Parotid duct: Injury to the parotid duct would result in issues related to salivation, such as a salivary fistula, but it would not cause motor weakness of the lower lip. This option is also incorrect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Weakness of the lower lip after parotid surgery is most likely due to injury to the cervical branch of the facial nerve. The marginal mandibular branch is the most specific, but if not listed, the cervical branch is the closest correct option

choices.text: Parasympathetic - bladder dysfunction and retrograde ejaculation.
Sympathetic - retrograde ejaculation and bladder dysfunction.
Sympathetic - Impotence and loss of cutaneous sensation in perineal region

questions.text: Identify the most common neurological complication following ligation of the Inferior mesenteric artery during abdominoperineal resection for rectal carcinoma? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Sympathetic - retrograde ejaculation and bladder dysfunction.

 

  • An abdominoperineal resection involves the removal of the left colon, pelvic floor, rectum, and anal canal.
  •  It is typically indicated for patients with operable low rectal carcinomas located within 5 cm of the anal verge.
  • The sympathetic innervation of the rectum originates from L1 – L3 spinal nerves, which form the superior hypogastric plexus.  
  • At the level of the sacral promontory, these nerves divide into the left and right hypogastric nerves, traveling on both sides of the pelvis.
  • These nerves supply the rectum and send branches to supply the genitourinary system anteriorly.
  • During pelvic surgeries, it is crucial to be aware of these nerves to avoid injuring them.
  • High ligation of the inferior mesenteric artery (IMA) near the sacral promontory may injure the superior hypogastric nerves, leading to sympathetic dysfunction.
  • This dysfunction is characterized by retrograde ejaculation and bladder dysfunction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Parasympathetic - bladder dysfunction and retrograde ejaculation: Parasympathetic nerves are less likely to be affected by the ligation of the IMA as their pathways are different. Parasympathetic innervation primarily involves the pelvic splanchnic nerves (S2-S4), which are not typically disrupted in this procedure.

 

Option B. Sympathetic - bladder dysfunction and impotence: While bladder dysfunction is a possible consequence of sympathetic nerve damage, impotence is not the most common result of injury to the sympathetic nerves. The more typical outcome includes retrograde ejaculation.

 

Option D. Sympathetic - Impotence and loss of cutaneous sensation in perineal region: Loss of cutaneous sensation in the perineal region would more likely result from damage to the pudendal nerve, not the sympathetic nerves. Impotence can occur but is less specific compared to retrograde ejaculation in the context of IMA ligation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • During abdominoperineal resection for rectal carcinoma, ligation of the inferior mesenteric artery may lead to sympathetic nerve damage, particularly the superior hypogastric plexus.
  • This can result in neurological complications such as retrograde ejaculation and bladder dysfunction.

choices.text: Soft tissue calcification in the neck

questions.text: A toddler was found playing alone and was brought to the emergency department with complaints of difficulty in swallowing for the past few hours. An X-ray was performed, and the image revealed as shown in AP view. What is the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Foreign body in the esophagus

 

  • A child presenting with difficulty in swallowing and the given X-ray suggest a foreign body lodged in the esophagus, most likely a coin or disc battery.
  • Anteroposterior (AP) and lateral views of the chest and neck X-rays were taken, and the flat surface of the coin in the esophagus is seen on the AP view, while the edge is seen on the lateral view.
  • Initial symptoms of esophageal foreign body ingestion include choking, gagging, and coughing, followed by excessive salivation, dysphagia, food refusal, vomiting, or pain in the neck and throat.
  • Respiratory symptoms such as stridor, wheezing, cyanosis, or dyspnea may also be seen.
  • Correct. If an object gets lodged in the esophagus, it can cause difficulty swallowing, pain, and drooling. The scenario presented indicates an X-ray showing a radiopaque foreign body (likely a coin or disc battery) in the esophagus, which is consistent with the child's symptoms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Foreign body in the trachea: When a foreign body is stuck in the trachea, it is a life-threatening situation as it can block airflow. Symptoms would typically include coughing, choking, wheezing, and difficulty breathing. The flat surface would be better seen in the lateral view.

 

Option C. Artifact: An artifact in radiology refers to any distortion or error in the image that is not present in the patient. Artifacts can be due to the equipment, the patient's movement, or other factors.

 

Option D. Soft tissue calcification in the neck: This refers to the presence of calcified deposits in the soft tissues of the neck. These can be due to various reasons, such as long-standing inflammation, tumors, or other diseases. However, the presentation of acute difficulty in swallowing and the X-ray findings make this option unlikely.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In cases of pediatric ingestion of foreign bodies, the esophagus is a common site where objects can become lodged.
  • Radiographic evaluation typically shows a foreign body in the esophagus with a flat surface seen on the AP view and the edge on the lateral view.
  •  Immediate recognition and appropriate intervention are crucial to prevent complications.

choices.text: Upper GI endoscopy and 24-hour PH monitoring

questions.text: A 45-year-old man comes to the clinic with a complaint of difficulty in swallowing both solids and liquids for the last eight months. A barium swallow test has been conducted, and the results are available for review. What further investigations are required for this patient? (AIIMS NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Upper GI endoscopy & Manometry

 

The given scenario of long standing dysphagia in a 45 year old, with barium swallow showing smooth tapering is suggestive of achalasia. Next investigations would be upper GI endoscopy (to rule of cancer) and esophageal manometry (IOC).

 

  • Upper GI endoscopy: This procedure involves a visual examination of the esophagus, allowing the physician to see any obstructions, lesions, or abnormalities that could be causing dysphagia like cancer
  • Manometry: Manometry measures the pressures and coordinated muscle contractions of the esophagus. It's particularly helpful for conditions like achalasia, where there's an absence of normal esophageal peristalsis and increased lower esophageal sphincter tone.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Upper GI endoscopy & PET scan: While a PET scan can identify metabolic activity and might be useful in detecting metastasis, it isn't a first-line test for dysphagia. The primary concern with dysphagia is often mechanical or functional obstruction, which a PET scan wouldn't directly address.

 

Option C. Upper GI endoscopy & CECT: CECT (Contrast-Enhanced Computed Tomography) can provide images of the esophagus, but it is not the primary modality for evaluating dysphagia. While it can identify masses or structural issues, it doesn't offer functional insights like manometry.

 

Option D. Upper GI endoscopy and 24-hour PH monitoring: 24-hour pH monitoring assesses the acidity in the esophagus over 24 hours. While it can be valuable for diagnosing conditions like GERD, it's not the primary investigation for dysphagia unless reflux symptoms are predominant

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Achalasia is a disorder of the esophagus characterized by absent peristalsis and impaired relaxation of the LES.
  • Manometry is the most sensitive test to diagnose achalasia and can identify early disease before esophageal dilatation and food retention.
  • The diagnostic criteria for achalasia with manometry are impaired LES relaxation, absent peristalsis, and elevated LES pressure. Subtypes are classified according to Chicago classification as Type 1 (classical), Type 2 (pan-esophageal pressurisation) and type 3 (Spastic).
  • Endoscopy can rule out pseudo achalasia/carcinoma.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male presents to the emergency department with multiple stab injuries to the chest. On examination, there is reduced chest movement on the right side and tracheal deviation to the left side. Additionally, the neck veins are distended. What is the next best step in the management of this patient? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Needle thoracocentesis

 

Patient with stab to chest with reduced chest movement on right, mediastinal shift to left with distended neck veins is suffering from tension pneumothorax. Next step is placement of wide bore needle in triangle of safety to decompress the pneumothorax, followed by ICD insertion.

 

This is the correct answer. Needle thoracocentesis is the next best step in the management of the patient with tension pneumothorax. It is a procedure that involves inserting a needle into the pleural space to aspirate the air or fluid. It is performed initially to decompress the tension pneumothorax in the triangle of safety (between Pect. Major anteriorly, Latissimus dorsi posteriorly, 5th intercostal space inferiorly).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Emergency room thoracotomy: This is not the next best step in the management of the patient with tension pneumothorax. Resuscitative thoracotomy is an emergency surgical procedure that is performed in the presence of cardiac arrest due to penetrating chest trauma.

 

Option B. ICD placement: This is not the next best step in the management of the patient with tension pneumothorax. An ICD (intercostal drainage) is a tube inserted into the pleural space to drain the air or fluid. ICD placement is the definitive management of tension pneumothorax but is not the next step in the management.

 

Option D. Finger thoracotomy: This is not the next best step in the management of the patient with tension pneumothorax. Finger thoracotomy is an alternative approach when needle decompression fails or is not possible. It involves making a small incision in the chest wall and using the finger to manually decompress the pneumothorax. However, needle decompression should be attempted first before considering finger thoracostomy.
